Dialogue.1: You make your way down the familiar wooden pier to the edge of the water, crouching to dip a hand into the lapping waves.
Dialogue.2: It's cold, of course, sending a shock through your arm and threatening to turn your hand numb if you leave it in much longer.
Dialogue.3: But you live for that feeling: the quiet electricity of the sea.
Dialogue.5: As you push off from the dock and cast your line into the water you notice another sailor already in the midst of the day's fishing.
Dialogue.6: He looks up as you row out toward him, and you instantly recognize the fisherman of local legend: Ol 'Enry himself.
Dialogue.8: "Ahoy there! Careful with ya oars; the bass be on high alert today!"
Dialogue.9: Strangely enough you've never spoken to the man yourself, though you've heard bits of his stories many a time walking into the Mermaid's Tale.
Dialogue.10: Guess this is your one chance to make a first impressionâ€”but what approach to take?
Dialogue.11: "Aye! Shiver me timbers if it ain't a fellow cap'n of the high seas! Ahoy and avast!"
Dialogue.12: Give a friendly nod and pull in your oars.
Dialogue.14: You draw on your years of practice and deliver the best pirate voice you've got****; and somehow, it seems to work!
Dialogue.15: "Blimey! Didn't wager I'd happen upon another voyager of the high seas today!"
Dialogue.16: "Where might your travails take ya on this bloody {time}?"
Dialogue.17: You tell him you were just moving the boat out to fish the dock (in your pirate voice of course), and he gives you a grizzled smile.
Dialogue.18: "Is that so! Might as well weigh anchor here, then, and keep an old fisherman company. I await tales of pillage and plunder!"
Dialogue.20: Yo ho ho and a bottle of rum! This new you is feeling more charismatic by the second. Maybe you should just speak like this all the time!
Dialogue.22: "Appreciate it.**** You know, the fish know far more than we give them credit for."
Dialogue.23: "They can feel when you come up on 'em with ill intent! Best to let ya ship drift in like yer just floating there."
Dialogue.24: "'Be one with the ocean and it be one with you' I always say!"
Dialogue.25: You can't tell if 'Enry expects a response, but by the time you've come up with something his gaze has already drifted back to his line.
Dialogue.26: Still, it's nice to have company as you while away a few hours, fishing side by side.
